query: What significant contributions did Adam Sedgwick make to the geological timescale, and how were these periods named?
reference_contexts:
['Adam Sedgwick FRS (; 22 March 1785 – 27 January 1873) was a British geologist and Anglican priest, one of the founders of modern geology.  He proposed the Cambrian and Devonian period of the geological timescale. Based on work which he did on Welsh rock strata, he proposed the Cambrian period in 1835, in a joint publication in which Roderick Murchison also proposed the Silurian period.  Later in 1840, to resolve what later became known as the Great Devonian Controversy about rocks near the boundary between the Silurian and Carboniferous periods, he and Murchison proposed the Devonian period.
Though he had guided the young Charles Darwin in his early study of geology and continued to be on friendly terms, Sedgwick was an opponent of Darwin's theory of evolution by means of natural selection.
He strongly opposed the admission of women to the University of Cambridge, in one conversation describing aspiring female students as "nasty forward minxes."


== Life and career ==
Sedgwick was born in Dent, Yorkshire, the third child of an Anglican vicar. He was educated at Sedbergh School and Trinity College, Cambridge.
He studied mathematics and theology, and obtained his BA (5th Wrangler) from the University of Cambridge in 1808 and his MA in 1811. On 20 July 1817 he was ordained a deacon, then a year later he was ordained as a priest. His academic mentors at Cambridge were Thomas Jones and John Dawson. He became a Fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge and Woodwardian Professor of Geology at Cambridge from 1818, holding the chair until his death in 1873. His biography in the Cambridge Alumni database says that upon his acceptance of the position, Sedgwick had no working knowledge of geology. An 1851 portrait of Sedgwick by William Boxall hangs in Trinity's collection.
Sedgwick studied the geology of the British Isles and Europe. He founded the system for the classification of Cambrian rocks and with Roderick Murchison worked out the order of the Carboniferous and underlying Devonian strata. These studies were mostly carried out in the 1830s. The investigations into the Devonian meant that Sedgwick was involved with Murchison in a vigorous debate with Henry De la Beche, in what became known as the great Devonian controversy.
He also employed John William Salter for a short time in arranging the fossils in the Woodwardian Museum at Cambridge, and whom accompanied the professor on several geological expeditions (1842–1845) into Wales. John Ruthven, with whom Sedgwick has a room at Kendal museum co-named after him, also frequently accompanied Sedgwick in Wales and beyond.
Sedgwick investigated the phenomena of metamorphism and concretion, and was the first to distinguish clearly between stratification, jointing, and slaty cleavage. He was elected to Fellow of the Royal Society on 1 February 1821. In 1844, he was elected a Foreign Honorary Member of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He was president of the Geological Society of London.


== Geological views and evolution ==

The Church of England, by no means a fundamentalist or evangelical church, encloses a wide range of beliefs. During Sedgwick's life there developed something of a chasm between the conservative high church believers and the liberal wing. After simmering for some years, the publication of Essays and Reviews by liberal churchmen in 1860 pinpointed the differences. In all this, Sedgwick, whose science and faith were intertwined in a natural theology, was definitely on the conservative side, and extremely outspoken about it. He told the February 1830 meeting of the Geological Society of London:

No opinion can be heretical, but that which is not true.... Conflicting falsehoods we can comprehend; but truths can never war against each other. I affirm, therefore, that we have nothing to fear from the results of our enquiries, provided they be followed in the laborious but secure road of honest induction. In this way we may rest assured that we shall never arrive at conclusions opposed to any truth, either physical or moral, from whatever source that truth may be derived ...
As a geologist in the mid-1820s he supported William Buckland's interpretation of certain superficial deposits, particularly loose rocks and gravel, as "diluvium" relating to worldwide floods, and in 1825 he published two papers identifying these as due to a "great irregular inundation" from the "waters of a general deluge", Noah's flood. Sedgwick's subsequent investigations and discussions with continental geologists persuaded him that this was problematic.']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick made several significant contributions to the geological timescale through his work on rock strata. He proposed two major geological periods:

1. **Cambrian Period**: In 1835, based on his studies of Welsh rock strata, Sedgwick proposed the Cambrian period in a joint publication with Roderick Murchison. This proposal was part of their efforts to classify and understand the sequence of ancient rocks.

2. **Devonian Period**: To address what became known as the Great Devonian Controversy regarding the classification of rocks near the boundary between the Silurian and Carboniferous periods, Sedgwick, along with Murchison, proposed the Devonian period in 1840. This helped clarify the geological timeline by distinguishing this new period.

These contributions were pivotal in establishing a more structured understanding of Earth's geological history. The names "Cambrian" and "Devonian" are derived from geographical locations: Cambria is an old name for Wales, where Sedgwick conducted much of his research on the Cambrian rocks; Devonian comes from Devonshire (now Devon), England, reflecting the region associated with these rock formations.

query: Describe the relationship between Adam Sedgwick and Charles Darwin, particularly focusing on their differing views on evolution.

Sedgwick's subsequent investigations and discussions with continental geologists persuaded him that this was problematic.']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick and Charles Darwin had a complex relationship characterized by both mentorship and ideological differences. Initially, Sedgwick played an influential role in guiding Darwin's early studies in geology. As a professor at the University of Cambridge, Sedgwick was one of Darwin’s mentors during his time as a student there. Despite their differing views on evolution later in life, they maintained friendly personal relations.

Sedgwick was a prominent figure in the field of geology and contributed significantly to the development of geological timescales by proposing the Cambrian and Devonian periods. However, he held conservative religious beliefs that were intertwined with his scientific work, adhering to natural theology—a perspective that sought to understand God's design through nature.

In contrast, Charles Darwin developed a theory of evolution by means of natural selection, which challenged traditional views on creation and posed significant implications for the understanding of life’s diversity. Sedgwick became an opponent of Darwin's evolutionary theory, reflecting his conservative stance within the Church of England. Despite their differing scientific perspectives, Sedgwick and Darwin continued to maintain a cordial relationship.

Their interactions highlight the broader tension between science and religion during that era, particularly as new scientific ideas began to challenge established religious doctrines. While Sedgwick supported interpretations of geological phenomena consistent with biblical accounts, such as attributing certain deposits to Noah's flood, he eventually recognized issues with these views through further investigation and dialogue with other geologists.

Overall, the relationship between Adam Sedgwick and Charles Darwin exemplifies a mentorship that evolved into a respectful disagreement over fundamental scientific theories.

query: How did Adam Sedgwick's religious beliefs influence his scientific work and public statements during his career?
reference_contexts:

reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick's religious beliefs significantly influenced both his scientific work and public statements throughout his career. As a devout Anglican priest, he integrated his faith with his scientific pursuits, adhering to the principles of natural theology, which sought to understand God through the study of nature.

1. **Natural Theology**: Sedgwick believed that science and religion were not in conflict but rather complementary. He saw truths derived from both physical observations and moral teachings as harmonious. This perspective is evident in his statement at the February 1830 meeting of the Geological Society of London, where he emphasized that honest scientific inquiry would never lead to conclusions opposed to any truth, whether physical or moral.

2. **Initial Support for Diluvialism**: In the mid-1820s, Sedgwick supported William Buckland's interpretation of certain geological deposits as "diluvium," relating them to Noah's flood. This view aligned with a literal interpretation of biblical events and reflected his initial attempt to reconcile scientific findings with religious doctrine.

3. **Shift in Geological Views**: Over time, discussions with continental geologists led Sedgwick to reconsider the diluvialist perspective, recognizing its limitations. Despite this shift, his conservative religious stance remained influential in how he approached geological questions and communicated his views publicly.

4. **Conservative Religious Stance**: During a period when debates within the Church of England were intensifying between conservative high church believers and liberal factions, Sedgwick aligned himself with the conservative side. His outspoken nature on these matters was evident in his reaction to the publication of "Essays and Reviews" by liberal churchmen in 1860.

5. **Opposition to Evolution**: Although he had guided Charles Darwin in early geological studies and maintained a friendly relationship, Sedgwick opposed Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection. This opposition can be seen as consistent with his conservative religious views, which likely influenced his resistance to ideas that challenged traditional interpretations of creation.

Overall, Adam Sedgwick's scientific work was deeply intertwined with his religious beliefs, shaping both his approach to geology and his public statements throughout his career.

query: How did Sedgwick's views on geology change after his visit to the Scottish Highlands with Roderick Murchison, and what external influences contributed to this shift?
reference_contexts:
['Sedgwick's subsequent investigations and discussions with continental geologists persuaded him that this was problematic. In early 1827, after spending several weeks in Paris, he visited geological features in the Scottish Highlands with Roderick Murchison. He later wrote "If I have been converted in part from the diluvian theory...it was...by my own gradual improved experience, and by communicating with those about me. Perhaps I may date my change of mind (at least in part) from our journey in the Highlands, where there are so many indications of local diluvial operations.... Humboldt ridiculed [the doctrine] beyond measure when I met him in Paris. Prévost lectured against it."  In response to Charles Lyell's 1830 publication, Principles of Geology, which is known for promoting uniformitarian geology Sedgwick talked of floods at various dates, then on 18 February 1831 when retiring from the Presidency of the Geological Society he recanted his former belief in Buckland's theory.
He strongly believed that species of organisms originated in a succession of Divine creative acts throughout the long expanse of history. Any form of development that denied a direct creative action smacked as materialistic and amoral. For Sedgwick, moral truths (the obtainment of which separates man from beast) were to be distinguished from physical truths, and to combine these or blur them together could only lead to disastrous consequences. In fact, one's own hope for immortality may ultimately rest on it.
He stated in 1830 that scriptural geologists proposed "a deformed progeny of heretical and fantastical conclusions, by which sober philosophy has been put to open shame, and sometimes even the charities of life have been exposed to violation." In 1834 he continued, "They have committed the folly and SIN of dogmatizing," having "sinned against plain sense," and "of writing mischievous nonsense," "Their eyes cannot bear to look upon" truth and suppose an "ignorant and dishonest" theory.  They show "bigotry and ignorance," of nature's laws and natural phenomena. Henry Cole then responded in 1834 in a 136-page "letter," Popular Geology Subversive of Divine Revelation. He referred to Sedgwick's ideas as "unscriptural and anti-Christian," "scripture-defying", "revelation-subverting," and "baseless speculations and self-contradictions," which were "impious and infidel".
While he became increasingly Evangelical with age, he strongly supported advances in geology against conservative churchmen. At the September 1844 British Association for the Advancement of Science meeting at York he achieved national celebrity for his reply defending modern geology against an attack by the Dean of York, the Reverend William Cockburn, who described it as unscriptural. The entire chapter house of the cathedral refused to sit down with Sedgwick, and he was opposed by conservative papers including The Times, but his courage was hailed by the full spectrum of the liberal press, and the confrontation was a key moment in the battle over relations between Scripture and science.

When Robert Chambers anonymously published his own theory of universal evolutionism as his "development hypothesis" in the book Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation published in October 1844 to immediate popular success, Sedgwick's many friends urged him to respond. Like other eminent scientists he initially ignored the book, but the subject kept recurring and he then read it carefully and made a withering attack on the book in the July 1845 edition of the Edinburgh Review. Vestiges "comes before [its readers] with a bright, polished, and many-coloured surface, and the serpent coils a false philosophy, and asks them to stretch out their hands and pluck the forbidden fruit", he wrote in his review. Accepting the arguments in Vestiges was akin to falling from grace and away from God's favour.
He lashed out at the book in a letter to Charles Lyell, bemoaning the consequences of it conclusions. "...If the book be true, the labours of sober induction are in vain; religion is a lie; human law is a mass of folly, and a base injustice; morality is moonshine; our labours for the black people of Africa were works of madmen; and man and woman are only better beasts!" Later, Sedgwick added a long preface to the 5th edition of his Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge (1850), including a lengthy attack on Vestiges and theories of development in general.
Charles Darwin was one of his geology students in 1831, and accompanied him on a field trip to Wales that summer. The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.']
reference_answer:
Sedgwick's views on geology underwent a significant transformation following his visit to the Scottish Highlands with Roderick Murchison in early 1827. Initially adhering to the diluvian theory, which posited that geological features were primarily shaped by catastrophic events like Noah's Flood, Sedgwick began to reconsider this stance during their journey through the Highlands. The region presented numerous indications of local diluvial operations, prompting him to question his previous beliefs.

Several external influences contributed to this shift in perspective:

1. **Interactions with Continental Geologists**: During a visit to Paris before heading to Scotland, Sedgwick engaged in discussions with prominent geologists like Alexander von Humboldt and Louis Prévost. Humboldt ridiculed the diluvian theory, while Prévost lectured against it, both of whom influenced Sedgwick's evolving views.

2. **Charles Lyell’s Uniformitarianism**: The publication of Charles Lyell's "Principles of Geology" in 1830 further impacted Sedgwick. Lyell promoted uniformitarian geology, which argued that the Earth was shaped by continuous and consistent processes over long periods rather than sudden catastrophic events. This perspective led Sedgwick to reconsider his earlier beliefs about diluvialism.

3. **Personal Reflections**: Sedgwick himself noted that his change of mind began during the journey in the Highlands, where he observed geological features firsthand. His gradual improved experience and communication with fellow geologists played a crucial role in this intellectual shift.

Ultimately, by February 18, 1831, when retiring from the Presidency of the Geological Society, Sedgwick recanted his former belief in William Buckland's diluvian theory, marking a significant change towards accepting more uniformitarian principles in geology.

query: What were Sedgwick's criticisms of scriptural geologists in 1830 and 1834, and how did he perceive their approach to understanding natural phenomena?
reference_contexts:
['Sedgwick's subsequent investigations and discussions with continental geologists persuaded him that this was problematic. In early 1827, after spending several weeks in Paris, he visited geological features in the Scottish Highlands with Roderick Murchison. He later wrote "If I have been converted in part from the diluvian theory...it was...by my own gradual improved experience, and by communicating with those about me. Perhaps I may date my change of mind (at least in part) from our journey in the Highlands, where there are so many indications of local diluvial operations.... Humboldt ridiculed [the doctrine] beyond measure when I met him in Paris. Prévost lectured against it."  In response to Charles Lyell's 1830 publication, Principles of Geology, which is known for promoting uniformitarian geology Sedgwick talked of floods at various dates, then on 18 February 1831 when retiring from the Presidency of the Geological Society he recanted his former belief in Buckland's theory.
He strongly believed that species of organisms originated in a succession of Divine creative acts throughout the long expanse of history. Any form of development that denied a direct creative action smacked as materialistic and amoral. For Sedgwick, moral truths (the obtainment of which separates man from beast) were to be distinguished from physical truths, and to combine these or blur them together could only lead to disastrous consequences. In fact, one's own hope for immortality may ultimately rest on it.
He stated in 1830 that scriptural geologists proposed "a deformed progeny of heretical and fantastical conclusions, by which sober philosophy has been put to open shame, and sometimes even the charities of life have been exposed to violation." In 1834 he continued, "They have committed the folly and SIN of dogmatizing," having "sinned against plain sense," and "of writing mischievous nonsense," "Their eyes cannot bear to look upon" truth and suppose an "ignorant and dishonest" theory.  They show "bigotry and ignorance," of nature's laws and natural phenomena. Henry Cole then responded in 1834 in a 136-page "letter," Popular Geology Subversive of Divine Revelation. He referred to Sedgwick's ideas as "unscriptural and anti-Christian," "scripture-defying", "revelation-subverting," and "baseless speculations and self-contradictions," which were "impious and infidel".
While he became increasingly Evangelical with age, he strongly supported advances in geology against conservative churchmen. At the September 1844 British Association for the Advancement of Science meeting at York he achieved national celebrity for his reply defending modern geology against an attack by the Dean of York, the Reverend William Cockburn, who described it as unscriptural. The entire chapter house of the cathedral refused to sit down with Sedgwick, and he was opposed by conservative papers including The Times, but his courage was hailed by the full spectrum of the liberal press, and the confrontation was a key moment in the battle over relations between Scripture and science.

When Robert Chambers anonymously published his own theory of universal evolutionism as his "development hypothesis" in the book Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation published in October 1844 to immediate popular success, Sedgwick's many friends urged him to respond. Like other eminent scientists he initially ignored the book, but the subject kept recurring and he then read it carefully and made a withering attack on the book in the July 1845 edition of the Edinburgh Review. Vestiges "comes before [its readers] with a bright, polished, and many-coloured surface, and the serpent coils a false philosophy, and asks them to stretch out their hands and pluck the forbidden fruit", he wrote in his review. Accepting the arguments in Vestiges was akin to falling from grace and away from God's favour.
He lashed out at the book in a letter to Charles Lyell, bemoaning the consequences of it conclusions. "...If the book be true, the labours of sober induction are in vain; religion is a lie; human law is a mass of folly, and a base injustice; morality is moonshine; our labours for the black people of Africa were works of madmen; and man and woman are only better beasts!" Later, Sedgwick added a long preface to the 5th edition of his Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge (1850), including a lengthy attack on Vestiges and theories of development in general.
Charles Darwin was one of his geology students in 1831, and accompanied him on a field trip to Wales that summer. The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.']
reference_answer:
In 1830, Adam Sedgwick criticized scriptural geologists by describing them as proponents of "a deformed progeny of heretical and fantastical conclusions," which he believed had brought "sober philosophy" into disrepute. He argued that their approach led to the violation of life's charities and was fundamentally flawed.

By 1834, Sedgwick intensified his criticisms, accusing scriptural geologists of committing a "folly and SIN of dogmatizing." He claimed they sinned against plain sense by writing what he considered "mischievous nonsense" and were unable or unwilling to acknowledge truth. According to Sedgwick, their approach was marked by "bigotry and ignorance," particularly concerning nature's laws and natural phenomena.

Overall, Sedgwick perceived the scriptural geologists' approach as one that rejected empirical evidence in favor of dogmatic interpretations, which he saw as both scientifically unsound and morally problematic. He believed they were blinded to truth and engaged in baseless speculation that undermined genuine scientific inquiry.

"...If the book be true, the labours of sober induction are in vain; religion is a lie; human law is a mass of folly, and a base injustice; morality is moonshine; our labours for the black people of Africa were works of madmen; and man and woman are only better beasts!" Later, Sedgwick added a long preface to the 5th edition of his Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge (1850), including a lengthy attack on Vestiges and theories of development in general.
Charles Darwin was one of his geology students in 1831, and accompanied him on a field trip to Wales that summer. The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick had a vehemently negative reaction to Robert Chambers' book "Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation." Initially, like many eminent scientists of his time, he ignored the publication. However, as discussions around it persisted, he eventually read the book carefully and responded with strong criticism.

Sedgwick's primary concern was that accepting the ideas presented in "Vestiges" would undermine fundamental aspects of society and belief systems. He believed that if Chambers' theory of universal evolutionism were true, it would render the efforts of scientific inquiry through sober induction meaningless. More profoundly, Sedgwick feared that such a perspective would challenge the very foundations of religion, suggesting that religious beliefs were false.

Moreover, he argued that accepting evolutionary ideas as proposed in "Vestiges" would lead to the collapse of human law and morality, reducing them to folly or injustice. He saw this as leading to moral relativism, where ethical principles could be dismissed as mere illusions ("moonshine"). Sedgwick also believed that humanitarian efforts, such as those aimed at helping African people, would appear misguided if humanity was viewed merely as an extension of animal evolution.

In his review in the Edinburgh Review and subsequent writings, including a preface to his "Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge," Sedgwick attacked the book's arguments. He likened its influence to that of a serpent offering forbidden fruit, suggesting that embracing such ideas would lead humanity away from divine favor and grace.

Overall, Sedgwick's reaction was rooted in his belief that accepting evolutionary theories like those proposed by Chambers threatened not only religious faith but also the moral and legal structures upon which society depended.

query: How did Adam Sedgwick's views on Charles Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" differ from his perspective on Vestiges, and what specific criticisms did he express about Darwin's methodology?
reference_contexts:
['Later, Sedgwick added a long preface to the 5th edition of his Discourse on the Studies of the University of Cambridge (1850), including a lengthy attack on Vestiges and theories of development in general.
Charles Darwin was one of his geology students in 1831, and accompanied him on a field trip to Wales that summer. The two kept up a correspondence while Darwin was on the Beagle expedition, and afterwards.  However, Sedgwick never accepted the case for evolution made in On the Origin of Species in 1859 any more than he did that in  Vestiges in 1844.  In response to receiving and reading Darwin's book, he wrote to Darwin saying:

If I did not think you a good tempered & truth loving man I should not tell you that... I have read your book with more pain than pleasure. Parts of it I admired greatly; parts I laughed at till my sides were almost sore; other parts I read with absolute sorrow; because I think them utterly false & grievously mischievous – You have deserted—after a start in that tram-road of all solid physical truth—the true method of induction—& started up a machinery as wild I think as Bishop Wilkins's locomotive that was to sail with us to the Moon. Many of your wide conclusions are based upon assumptions which can neither be proved nor disproved. Why then express them in the language & arrangements of philosophical induction?
Sedgwick regarded natural selection as

but a secondary consequence of supposed, or known, primary facts. Development is a better word because more close to the cause of the fact. For you do not deny causation. I call (in the abstract) causation the will of God: & I can prove that He acts for the good of His creatures. He also acts by laws which we can study &  comprehend—Acting by law, & under what is called final cause, comprehends, I think, your whole principle ...
He emphasised his distinction between the moral and physical aspects of life, "There is a moral or metaphysical part of nature as well as a physical. A man who denies this is deep in the mire of folly". If humanity broke this distinction it "would suffer a damage that might brutalize it—& sink the human race into a lower grade of degradation than any into which it has fallen since its written records tell us of its history".
In a letter to another correspondent, Sedgwick was even harsher on Darwin's book, calling it "utterly false" and writing that "It repudiates all reasoning from final causes; and seems to shut the door on any view (however feeble) of the God of Nature as manifested in His works. From first to last it is a dish of rank materialism cleverly cooked and served up".
Despite this difference of opinion, the two men remained friendly until Sedgwick's death. In contrast to Sedgwick, liberal church members (who included biologists such as George Rolleston, William Henry Flower and William Kitchen Parker) were usually comfortable with evolution.


== Links and opposition to slavery ==
As a co-trustee of the will of Ann Sill, an owner of slaves in plantations in Jamaica, in 1835 Sedgwick was awarded half of £3,783 in compensation for 174 slaves, following the abolition of slavery by the British government. Sedgwick is listed in the University College London database, Centre for the Study of the Legacies of British Slave Ownership, as being an awardee in receipt of £3,783 1s 8d on 8 February 1836 for "174 Enslaved". He was one of 46,000 people paid compensation during the abolition of slavery in the United Kingdom. A liberal Whig in politics, Sedgwick had long been a passionate supporter of abolition. In a letter to Bishop Wilberforce, dated July 16, 1848, Sedgwick wrote of signing a petition against the slave trade while he was a child—the first "political act of [his] life"—after his father had shown him "ugly pictures of the horrors of slavery".']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick's views on Charles Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" were similar to his perspective on Vestiges in that he rejected both works' theories of evolution. However, his criticism of Darwin was more detailed and focused specifically on Darwin's methodology.

Sedgwick criticized Darwin for abandoning what he considered the true method of induction—a systematic approach to scientific inquiry based on observation and evidence—by introducing ideas that Sedgwick saw as speculative and unprovable. He described Darwin's conclusions as being based on assumptions that could neither be proved nor disproved, which he found problematic when expressed in the language and structure of philosophical induction.

Sedgwick also viewed natural selection, a key component of Darwin's theory, as merely a secondary consequence rather than a primary cause of development. He preferred the term "development" because it was closer to what he believed were the true causes of observed facts. Sedgwick maintained that causation was an expression of divine will and argued that God acted for the good of His creatures through comprehensible laws, which encompassed Darwin's principle under a framework of final cause.

In summary, while Sedgwick rejected both Vestiges and "On the Origin of Species," his specific criticisms of Darwin focused on what he saw as methodological flaws and speculative assumptions in Darwin's work.

In a letter to Bishop Wilberforce, dated July 16, 1848, Sedgwick wrote of signing a petition against the slave trade while he was a child—the first "political act of [his] life"—after his father had shown him "ugly pictures of the horrors of slavery".']
reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick reconciled his scientific beliefs with his religious convictions by maintaining a clear distinction between moral/metaphysical aspects of nature and physical ones. He viewed the concept of development as more aligned with causation than natural selection, which he saw as merely a secondary consequence of primary facts. For Sedgwick, causation was synonymous with divine will—specifically, "the will of God"—and he believed that God acted for the good of His creatures through comprehensible laws.

Sedgwick emphasized that understanding nature involved studying these laws and recognizing what he termed "final causes," which encompassed his entire principle. He argued that denying a moral or metaphysical dimension to nature was foolish, as it could lead humanity into degradation. This perspective allowed him to critique Darwin's theory of natural selection for its perceived materialism and rejection of reasoning from final causes.

Despite rejecting the evolutionary framework proposed by Darwin, Sedgwick maintained his friendship with Darwin, indicating that he separated personal relationships from scientific disagreements. His approach reflects an attempt to integrate his religious beliefs with his scientific work by framing natural phenomena within a theological context while still engaging in scientific inquiry.

reference_answer:
Adam Sedgwick's political stance on slavery was firmly against it, as evidenced by his actions and beliefs throughout his life. Despite receiving compensation for slaves following their emancipation—a common practice at the time—Sedgwick had long been a passionate supporter of abolition.

His commitment to ending slavery manifested early in his life when he signed a petition against the slave trade while still a child. This act was described as the first "political act" of his life, spurred by his father showing him "ugly pictures of the horrors of slavery." This early action demonstrated Sedgwick's deep-seated opposition to slavery and set the tone for his lifelong advocacy.

As an adult, Sedgwick maintained a liberal Whig political stance, which aligned with his abolitionist views. His receipt of compensation following the British government's abolition of slavery did not contradict his anti-slavery position; rather, it was part of the broader legal and financial context of that period. Despite this, his consistent support for abolition and his early actions against the slave trade underscored his genuine commitment to ending slavery.

query: In what year was the Sedgwick Museum completed and opened, and who played a key role in its establishment?
reference_contexts:
['== Legacy ==

The Sedgwick Club, the oldest student-run geological society in the world, was set up in honour of him in 1880.
On the death of Sedgwick it was decided that his memorial should take the form of a new and larger museum. There was brief, later discarded, talk of opening a Sedgwick youth summer programme. Hitherto the geological collections had been placed in the Woodwardian Museum in Cockerell's Building. Through the energy of Professor T. McK. Hughes (successor to Sedgwick) the new building, termed the Sedgwick Museum, was completed and opened in 1903.
In 1865, the University of Cambridge received from A. A. Van Sittart the sum of 500 pounds sterling "for the purpose of encouraging the study of geology among the resident members of the university, and in honour of the Rev. Adam Sedgwick". Thus was founded the Sedgwick Prize to be given every third year for the best essay on some geological subject. The first Sedgwick Prize was awarded in 1873 and has continued into the 21st century.
To celebrate the bicentenary of Sedgwick's birth a geological trail was created near Dent, the village where he was born and developed his passion for geology (amongst other things). The Sedgwick Trail follows the River Clough, highlighting rock features and exploring the Dent Fault.
Mount Sedgwick in British Columbia, Canada, was officially named after him in 1951.


== Notes ==


== References ==
Chisholm, Hugh, ed. (1911). "Sedgwick, Adam" . Encyclopædia Britannica. Vol. 24 (11th ed.). Cambridge University Press. pp. 557–558.
J.W. Clark and T.M. Hughes, The Life and Letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick, Cambridge University Press, 1890, vols. 1–2. (Reissued by Cambridge University Press, 2010. ISBN 978-1-108-01831-9)
Dictionary of Scientific Biography, Charles Scribner's Sons: 1970–1990; vol. 12, pp. 275–279.
A Biographical Dictionary of Scientists, Williams, T. I., Ed., Wiley, 1969, pp. 467–468.
Isaac Asimov, I. Asimov's Biographical Encyclopedia of Science and Technology (2nd Ed.), Doubleday: 1982, p. 299.
Quart. J. Geol. Soc., 1873, 29, pp. xxx–xxxix.
Bonney, Thomas George (1889). "Sedgwick, Adam" . In Stephen, Leslie (ed.). Dictionary of National Biography. Vol. 17. London: Smith, Elder & Co. pp. 179–182.
"Adam Sedgwick – Geologist and Dalesman" Colin Speakman Broad Oak Press 1982.
"Adam Sedgwick's Dent"  A facsimile reprint of 'A Memorial by the Trustees of Cowgill Chapel (1868) and 'Supplement to the Memorial (1870) by Adam Sedgwick with introduction by David Boulton Hollett, Sedbergh and David Boulton Dent 1984.
"A Discourse on the Studies of the University" Adam Sedgwick The Victorian Library, Leicester University Press 1969
Browne, E. Janet (1995), Charles Darwin: vol. 1 Voyaging, London: Jonathan Cape, ISBN 1-84413-314-1
Herbert, Sandra (1991), "Charles Darwin as a prospective geological author", British Journal for the History of Science, vol. 24, no. 2, pp. 159–192, doi:10.1017/s0007087400027060, S2CID 143748414, archived from the original on 8 February 2009, retrieved 24 January 2009
Secord, James A. (2000), Victorian Sensation: the extraordinary publication, reception, and secret authorship of Vestiges of the natural history of creation, Chicago: University of Chicago Press, ISBN 0-226-74411-6


== External links ==

Sedgwick Museum, Cambridge
Works by or about Adam Sedgwick at the Internet Archive
The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.1 by J.W.Clark, 1890
The life and letters of the Reverend Adam Sedgwick Vol.2 by J.W.Clark, 1890
Obituary in: "Obituary" . Popular Science Monthly. Vol. 2. April 1873.']
reference_answer: The Sedgwick Museum was completed and opened in 1903. A key figure in its establishment was Professor T. McK. Hughes, who succeeded Adam Sedgwick and played an instrumental role through his energy and efforts to bring the new building to fruition. The museum was named in honor of Adam Sedgwick, reflecting his significant contributions to geology and education at the University of Cambridge.

reference_answer:
The Sedgwick Prize was established by A. A. Van Sittart in 1865 with the purpose of encouraging the study of geology among resident members of the University of Cambridge and to honor the Reverend Adam Sedgwick, a prominent figure in the field of geology. The prize is awarded every third year for the best essay on some geological subject. It was first awarded in 1873.

**Key Points:**

- **Purpose:** To promote the study of geology at the University of Cambridge and to honor Adam Sedgwick.
- **Establishment Year:** 1865
- **First Awarded:** 1873

This initiative reflects the lasting impact of Adam Sedgwick's contributions to geology and his influence on academic pursuits in this field.

reference_answer:
To celebrate the bicentenary of Adam Sedgwick's birth, a geological trail was created near Dent, the village where he was born. This event is significant as it honors Sedgwick's contributions to geology and his connection to the area. The geographical feature involved in this celebration is the River Clough, which the Sedgwick Trail follows. Along this trail, rock features are highlighted, and the Dent Fault is explored, providing an educational experience that reflects Sedgwick's passion for geology.

The creation of the Sedgwick Trail serves not only as a tribute to his legacy but also as an opportunity for visitors to engage with the geological aspects of the region. By following the River Clough and examining various rock formations and faults, participants can gain insights into the natural history that fascinated Sedgwick throughout his life. This trail thus stands as both a commemorative landmark and an educational resource, linking Sedgwick's historical impact with contemporary appreciation for geology.
